Cables snaked across the wooden floor like thick, black ivy, and instruments stood silent on their stands – guitars, a cello, a grand piano – like patient, sleeping animals. A man was hunched over the mixing desk, his back to her. He was older than she’d expected, with a shock of unruly grey hair and a worn leather jacket, despite the warmth of the room. He didn’t turn around when she entered. “You’re late,” he said, his voice a low, gravelly rumble that sounded like it had been cured in whisky and cigarettes. “Traffic from Dover?” Eleanor, who was in fact ten minutes early, felt a prickle of annoyance. “Hello. I’m Eleanor Vance,” she said, placing Bartholomew’s box gently on a side table. “And no, there was no traffic.” He finally swiveled in his chair, his eyes, small and startlingly blue in a weary, lined face, taking her in. This was Julian Croft, the producer. A man whose name was whispered in reverent tones on music documentaries, a purist who had famously walked out of a multi-million-dollar pop album because the singer couldn’t hold a note. “I know who you are,” he grunted. “You’re the gimmick. The schoolteacher with the golden tonsils and the pet fish. Let’s see if any of it’s real.”

He gestured towards the vocal booth, a glass-walled room in the corner. “Go on then. Sing something. No music. Just you. Let’s hear what Sony’s spent all this money on.” His tone was dismissive, bored, the tone of a man who had seen it all and was profoundly unimpressed by this latest curiosity. Eleanor felt a familiar knot of performance anxiety tighten in her stomach. This was different from the BGT stage; there was no vast, anonymous crowd, just the focused, cynical gaze of one man who held her musical future in his hands. She took a deep breath, walked into the booth, and put on the heavy headphones. She carefully positioned Bartholomew’s bowl on a small stool she’d brought in with her, so she could see him through the glass. The silence in the headphones was absolute. She looked at Julian, who was watching her with his arms crossed, his expression unreadable. She decided against the Celtic laments, the songs that had become her calling card. She chose something else, a song she had written herself in her new notebook, inspired by Lily’s drawing. It was a simple, quiet song about looking out at a vast, starry sky from a small, safe window. She began to sing, her voice soft and unadorned, the melody clear and true.

As she sang, she watched Julian. For the first verse, he remained motionless, his cynical mask firmly in place. But as she moved into the chorus, a quiet, soaring melody that spoke of hope and perspective, she saw a flicker of change. He leaned forward slightly, his head tilted, his fingers tapping a silent rhythm on the arm of his chair. He was no longer looking at her as a gimmick; he was listening to the song. He was deconstructing the melody, analysing the structure, hearing the quiet truth in the lyrics. When she finished, the silence that followed was heavy and evaluative. He stared at her through the glass for a long moment, his blue eyes narrowed in thought. Then he pressed a button on the console, his gravelly voice crackling in her headphones. “Okay,” he said, and the single word was devoid of praise, but it was also entirely free of contempt. “The lyrics need work. A bit sentimental. But the melodic structure is sound. And the voice is clean. There’s no artifice in it. I can work with that.” He paused. “Sing it again.”

The days that followed fell into an intense, monastic rhythm. Julian was a relentless, exacting taskmaster, but his focus was not on making her sound more commercial; it was on making her sound more herself. He was a musical archaeologist, carefully brushing away any dust of sentimentality or performance to get to the pure, honest fossil of the song beneath. He made her sing a single phrase twenty times in a row, not to get it technically perfect, but to get it emotionally true. "Don't 'perform' it, Eleanor," he would rasp through the intercom, his voice a constant, critical presence in her ear. "Just tell the story. You're an English teacher. You know how to tell a story." He stripped back the arrangements, discarding lush strings and complex harmonies in favour of a single acoustic guitar, the mournful notes of a cello, or the stark, simple beauty of her voice alone. He seemed to have an almost allergic reaction to anything that sounded too polished or too produced.

Strangely, he never once commented on Bartholomew. He simply accepted the fishbowl in the vocal booth as a non-negotiable part of the setup, another piece of studio equipment like a microphone or a pop shield. One afternoon, after a particularly grueling session working on a heart-wrenching ballad about her mother, Eleanor was packing up to leave, her voice raw and her spirit weary. Julian was hunched over the mixing desk, listening back to the take. “He helps, doesn’t he?” he said suddenly, not looking up. Eleanor paused. “Bartholomew?” “The fish,” Julian clarified, still staring at the soundwaves dancing on his screen. “He keeps you grounded. Stops you from playing to the gallery. You sing to him, not to the idea of an audience. It’s why there’s no performance in your voice. It’s a conversation.” He finally turned to look at her, a flicker of something that looked almost like a smile on his face. “Don’t ever lose that. Or the fish.” It was in that moment that Eleanor knew she was in the right place. He understood. He saw the window, not just the bowl.

Each evening, she would return to a small, rented flat not far from the studio, a place with a comfy armchair and a view of a leafy park. It was a world away from the five-star luxury Sarah had envisioned for her. Here, she would make herself a simple dinner, call Brenda to get the latest on the school’s budget crisis and who had been caught smoking behind the bike sheds, and spend an hour marking a stack of summer holiday prep work she had brought with her. The familiar red pen, the spidery handwriting of her students, the predictable grammatical errors – it was an anchor, a ritual that connected her to the other half of her life. She would sit in the quiet of the London evening, the distant roar of the city a mere whisper, and feel a profound sense of integration. The woman who debated the use of the semicolon with Year 10 was the same woman who had argued with a legendary producer about a chord progression that afternoon. She was not two separate people. She was whole. The last thing she did before turning in was to listen to the rough mixes Julian had sent her. Hearing her own voice, clean and true, woven with the spare, beautiful instrumentation, she felt a quiet, powerful thrill. This was not a spectacle. This was not a competition. This was creation. She was not just singing her songs; she was building her window.The final day in the studio felt like the last day of a long, peaceful summer term. A quiet, melancholic sense of completion hung in the air, thick as the scent of dust motes dancing in the beams of light from the high windows. The grand piano stood with its lid open, its keys having been played with a delicate, almost reverential touch. The cello leaned in its corner, its voice now captured and confined to a hard drive. For the final track, Julian had insisted on returning to the beginning. The album would close with *She Moved Through the Fair*. Not the heart-wrenching, high-note-chasing version of the BGT final, but a rendition pared back to its bones, recorded in a single, unedited take. It was no longer a lament for a ghost, but a conversation with a memory, peaceful and resolved. Eleanor sang it with her eyes closed, her voice a low, clear thread of sound in the quiet room, with only the faintest whisper of an acoustic guitar for company. It was the sound of a wound that had finally, beautifully, healed.

When the last note faded, no one spoke for a full minute. Julian sat at the great desk, his head bowed, listening to the silence that followed. He did not offer praise or criticism; he simply nodded once to the sound engineer, a curt, definitive gesture. "That's a wrap," he said, his voice softer than usual. The quiet efficiency of packing up felt ceremonial. Eleanor carefully dried the outside of Bartholomew’s bowl, preparing him for the journey home. Julian burned a master copy of the album onto a single, unmarked silver disc and handed it to her, their fingers brushing. It felt heavy, like a medal. "Don't let them remix it for the radio," he grunted, his gaze fixed on the disc in her hand. "The silences are as important as the notes. Sarah will want to fill them with synth pads. Don't let her." He walked her to the door of the studio, a gesture of respect she knew he did not offer to everyone. As she stood on the threshold, he glanced down at the carrier box in her hand. "Tell the fish he has a good ear," he said, and with that, he turned and disappeared back into the shadows of his control room, leaving Eleanor alone in the London sunlight with her album and her accomplice.

The drive back to Dover was set to the soundtrack of her own voice. She slid the silver disc into the car’s CD player, her heart thrumming, and listened. It was a strange, out-of-body experience to hear the finished product, the collection of sounds that had been painstakingly assembled over the long, hot summer. It was her voice, yes, but it was also Julian’s spare, perfect arrangements, the soulful sigh of the cello, the quiet, intricate work of the acoustic guitar. It sounded like honesty. It sounded like the grey light over the Channel and the worn spines of old books. By the time the white cliffs rose up to greet her, she knew every note, every breath, every carefully preserved silence by heart. She was not just returning home; she was bringing the harvest with her. The new school year began on a Tuesday. Stepping back into the familiar, chaotic embrace of the staffroom was like putting on a favourite old cardigan. The album, which had been the sun her life had orbited for six weeks, was suddenly a distant star. The conversation was of new timetables, problematic students, and the eternally disappointing quality of the coffee. It was grounding, it was real, and it was wonderful. Brenda cornered her with the week’s sports results from the local paper, as if they had only been apart for a weekend. "Finished with all that caterwauling in London, have we?" she asked, her eyes scanning the football scores. "Good. The Year 11s have their mock exams in six weeks. They’ll need you at your best."

The call from Sarah came on a Friday afternoon, while Eleanor was trying to explain the concept of iambic pentameter to a particularly resistant Year 9 class. She let it go to voicemail, but Sarah, relentless as ever, immediately sent a text. ‘CALL ME. URGENT. IT’S HAPPENING.’ Eleanor waited until the final bell, until the last student had drifted out, before returning the call, standing by the large window in her empty classroom. "They love it," Sarah said, her voice fizzing with a triumphant energy that felt a world away from the quiet room. "Julian has performed a miracle. The label are ecstatic. They see it now – the authenticity, the purity. They want to lead with the one you wrote. 'Window'. It's being sent to the radio networks tonight. The official release date for the single is next Friday. Ken Bruce on Radio 2 has the world exclusive play on Monday morning, just after the nine o'clock news." Eleanor’s grip tightened on the phone. Monday morning. She would be here, in this room, teaching this class. "There's a media blitz planned," Sarah continued, "but we're sticking to the deal. Weekend interviews only. For now, just… get ready, Eleanor. The world is about to hear your song."

Monday morning arrived, grey and damp, a typical Dover autumn day. The nine o’clock news bulletin on the radio in the corner of the staffroom, usually ignored background noise, seemed to have a captive audience. Phil from PE had turned it up, and a small group of teachers were gathered around it, pretending to be engrossed in making their tea. Eleanor sat at her desk, a stack of essays in front of her, her red pen held in a white-knuckled grip, her heart hammering a frantic, un-poetic rhythm against her ribs. She felt utterly exposed, as if the radio were a giant ear pressed against her soul. The news finished. Ken Bruce’s familiar, avuncular voice filled the room. "And now," he said, his tone warm and conspiratorial, "for something very special indeed. You’ll know her from Britain’s Got Talent, but this is something else entirely. A new voice, but an old soul. Making her radio debut, this is Eleanor Vance, with 'Window'." A beat of silence, one of Julian’s carefully guarded silences, and then the sound of a single, clean acoustic guitar chord filled the staffroom. And then, her voice. It was strange and intimate, hearing it here, in this shabby, beloved room, surrounded by her colleagues. It was her, stripped back and true, her lyrics about the stars and the safety of her small room weaving through the air, mingling with the smell of stale coffee and chalk dust. No one spoke. Brenda stared intently into her mug. Phil stood frozen, a half-eaten biscuit in his hand. As the final, gentle chord faded, Ken Bruce’s voice returned, softer than before. "Well," he said, after a beat. "I think we'll all be needing a moment after that one. That was Eleanor Vance. Remember the name." And then, with a jarring shift of tone, he introduced the next track, a brash, upbeat pop song from a band she’d never heard of. The spell was broken. The staffroom exhaled as one. Phil let out a low whistle. "Blimey, Eleanor," he said, finally taking a bite of his biscuit. "That was… proper."

Eleanor didn’t hear him. She was staring out of the staffroom window, at the grey sky, at the familiar rooftops of the town. Her song, her small, private creation, was out there. It was travelling on radio waves across the country, pouring into kitchens and cars and offices, a secret whispered to millions. She felt a profound, dizzying sense of release, not of anxiety. She had not just sung from the window; she had opened it, and let the song fly free. Whatever happened now, whether it soared or fell, was beyond her control. She picked up her red pen, her hand suddenly steady, and drew a neat circle around a misplaced apostrophe in the top essay. She had a job to do.The pop song that followed her own was a jarring blast of manufactured joy, and it acted like a starter pistol, jolting the staffroom back into its morning routine. Mugs were rinsed, bags were gathered, and the low hum of professional life resumed. But something had fundamentally shifted. As Eleanor walked towards her classroom for the second lesson of the day, the corridors felt different. The usual boisterous chaos of students moving between lessons was subtly subdued in her vicinity. It was as if she were moving in a pocket of quiet respect. Students didn't just step aside for her; they watched her pass, their faces a mixture of awe and dawning comprehension. She wasn’t just the teacher who had been on the telly anymore. She was the voice from the radio. She was real in a way that television, with its aura of distant spectacle, had never quite allowed.

Her next class was Year 11, and the topic was Keats’s ‘Ode to a Nightingale,’ a poem about the painful beauty of a song that offers an escape from the weariness of the world. As she read the lines aloud – ‘My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains / My sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk’ – she felt the words with a new, acute resonance. The students were utterly silent, their attention absolute. When she finished, she looked up and saw not the usual glazed expressions, but faces full of thoughtful consideration. A quiet boy named Sam, the same one whose essay on ‘An Inspector Calls’ had so impressed her, raised his hand. “Miss,” he began, his voice hesitant, “is that what your song is about? The one on the radio this morning?” Eleanor felt a familiar professional instinct to steer the conversation back to the set text, but she paused, recognising the genuine curiosity. “What do you mean, Sam?” she asked. “Well,” he said, gaining confidence, “Keats wants to escape with the nightingale, into the forest. But he knows he can’t really. He has to stay here, in the real world where people get sick and old. Your song… it’s like you’re not trying to escape. You’re just… looking out the window at it all. From somewhere safe.” The simple, profound analysis landed in the quiet classroom with the force of a revelation. This was what she did. This was why she was here. She was not just teaching poetry; she was living it, and in doing so, she was making its difficult, beautiful truths accessible. “That,” she said, her voice catching slightly, “is an absolutely exceptional reading, Sam. Both of the poem, and of the song.”

At lunchtime, she retreated to the sanctuary of her empty classroom, a cheese and pickle sandwich in one hand, her phone in the other. She had avoided it all morning, but she could no longer ignore the small, black portal to the other world. The screen lit up with a reality so far removed from the school canteen that it felt like science fiction. Her name was trending on Twitter. The hashtag #Window was a torrent of emotional reactions from strangers. ‘Cried on my commute.’ ‘Who IS Eleanor Vance?’ ‘My new favourite song.’ There were links to articles that had sprung up in the last two hours. ‘The breakout star of 2023?’ one headline asked. ‘From BGT Runner-Up to National Treasure in a Single Morning.’ It was abstract, overwhelming, and felt as though it were happening to a distant cousin with the same name. Sarah called then, her voice not just fizzing, but practically incandescent. “Number nine on the iTunes chart already! Nine! From one radio play! The streaming numbers are astronomical. I’ve had Good Morning Britain on the phone, Lorraine, The One Show… they all want you. We can have you on a sofa in London by tomorrow morning.” Eleanor took a slow bite of her sandwich, the familiar tang of the pickle a grounding sensation. “Sarah, I can’t tomorrow,” she said calmly. “I have a full day of lessons, and then a Year 7 parents’ evening until eight o’clock.” A noise came down the phone line, a sound of pure, strangled frustration. “A parents’ evening? A parents’ evening? Your song is about to be a national hit and you’re talking about a parents’ evening?” “I am,” Eleanor said, her voice firm. “I have appointments with thirty-four sets of parents who want to know how their children are settling into secondary school. It’s important. We agreed, Sarah. Weekends only.” The silence on the other end was a testament to the battle raging in the producer’s mind between commercial instinct and the bizarre terms of their contract. “Fine,” Sarah finally snapped, the word clipped and sharp. “Fine. But you are doing Graham Norton next Friday. It’s already booked. Don’t tell me you have a school disco.” The line went dead. Eleanor finished her sandwich in the quiet of her classroom, the distant shouts from the playground a more comforting soundtrack than any pop chart countdown.

The true collision of her two worlds came at three-thirty. As the final bell rang and the school began to empty, Eleanor looked out her window and saw him. A man with a long-lensed camera, leaning against the wall opposite the school gates, a telephoto lens aimed directly at the entrance. The flight had been first class, a private pod of cream leather and polished wood, a space of hushed service and limitless champagne. The flight attendant, a kind woman with a warm, professional smile, had treated her with a gentle reverence, having clearly been briefed on who she was. "Ms. Vance, can I get you a drink before take-off? Some champagne, perhaps?" Eleanor had politely requested a sparkling water. "And for dinner, the chef has prepared a pan-seared sea bass or a filet mignon…" Eleanor had nodded, thanked her, and then, as soon as the plane reached cruising altitude and the seatbelt sign pinged off, she had clicked on her small reading light, pulled the heavy stack of essays from her bag, and uncapped her red pen. For the next nine hours, as the aircraft sped across the Atlantic at six hundred miles per hour, Eleanor Vance sat in her luxurious cocoon and meticulously, thoughtfully, marked her students’ work. She corrected their spelling, she questioned their analysis of Lady Macbeth’s ambition, she circled their clumsy phrasing and wrote suggestions in the margins in her neat, controlled cursive. At one point, the flight attendant, coming to clear her dinner plate, had paused, her eyes falling on the sea of red ink and earnest teenage handwriting. She’d looked at the paper, then at Eleanor, her expression one of utter, baffled bewilderment, before simply smiling and backing away, as if from a rare and incomprehensible creature performing a sacred, unknowable ritual. By the time the plane began its descent over the sun-bleached landscape of California, she had marked forty-eight of the sixty-two papers. It had been, she reflected, one of the most productive flights of her life.

Her rehearsal was not until the following morning, leaving her with an evening alone in the cavernous, silent hotel room. The loneliness should have been crushing, but she found it strangely peaceful. She ordered a simple club sandwich from room service, the price of which could have fed her for a week in Dover, and sat at the desk, working her way through the remaining fourteen essays. The final paper belonged to Sam, the quiet, thoughtful boy who had seen the truth in her song. His essay was, as expected, exceptional; a nuanced, insightful exploration of guilt and masculinity. On the final page, she wrote her feedback, finishing with the words, ‘An outstanding piece of analysis, Sam. You have a genuine gift for literary criticism. Well done.’ She capped her red pen, stacked the marked papers neatly, and tied the rubber band back around them. The job was done. Her responsibilities were met. Now, and only now, could she allow herself to think about the Grammys. She walked to the vast window and looked out at the city, a breathtaking, infinite carpet of light under a bruised purple sky. Somewhere down there was the arena where, in less than forty-eight hours, she would stand on a stage and sing to a billion people. She felt a tremor of fear, but it was a clean, sharp fear, not the murky anxiety of the past. It was the healthy, professional nervousness of an athlete before a race, a surgeon before an operation. It was the fear of not doing justice to the task. She held the small, cool stone from Dover in the palm of her hand, its familiar weight a connection to the other side of the world, to her classroom, to her home. She was ready.

The Staples Center was a city within a city, a labyrinth of concrete corridors, echoing loading bays, and frantic, purposeful activity. The scale of the operation was staggering, making the BGT final feel like a school play by comparison. The air buzzed with the high-frequency hum of organised chaos, a symphony of crackling walkie-talkies, rumbling flight cases, and shouted instructions. Eleanor was escorted by a quiet, efficient young woman through the bewildering maze to a small, private rehearsal studio deep in the bowels of the building. Waiting for her was the show’s musical director, a legendary figure named Marcus Bell, a man with kind, tired eyes and more music history in his little finger than most people have in their whole lives. He rose when she entered, shaking her hand warmly. There was no cynicism in his gaze, no hint that he was dealing with a novelty act. His expression was one of quiet, sober respect. "Ms. Vance. An honour," he said, his voice a low, gentle baritone. "Thank you for doing this. It's the most important two minutes of the show, and we need to get it right."

The musicians, a small ensemble of LA’s finest session players on piano, cello, and acoustic guitar, were already in place. The mood in the room was calm and reverent, a pocket of stillness amidst the backstage hurricane. Marcus did not ask her to warm up or to run scales. He spoke to her about the artists who had passed away that year, sharing small, personal anecdotes about the ones he had known. He spoke of their legacies, of the holes they had left, of the importance of honouring their memory with grace and simplicity. He was not just directing a performance; he was curating an act of remembrance. "The song we've chosen," he said, looking at her directly, "is 'Both Sides, Now'. Joni's masterpiece. It's a song about perspective, about learning to see things clearly as you get older. It felt… right for you. And for them." He handed her the sheet music, but she already knew the song by heart. It was one of the first songs she had ever learned to play on the guitar, a song she had sung quietly to herself for decades. It was perfect. "Okay, Eleanor," Marcus said gently, turning to the musicians. "Let's just walk through it. From the top. Whenever you're ready." Eleanor took her place at the microphone, the small, quiet room a world away from the vast, empty arena just a few floors above. She closed her eyes, thought of the faces of the musicians she was there to honour, and with the first, gentle notes from the piano, she began to sing.The song unfolded in the quiet studio, not as a performance, but as a confession. Eleanor sang the first verse of ‘Both Sides, Now’ with a hesitant, exploratory delicacy, her voice tracing the famous melody like a finger tracing a line on a dusty map. She sang of clouds and love and life as illusions she was just beginning to understand, her interpretation coloured by the quiet melancholy of her own contained experience. The musicians played with a sublime, understated grace, their notes falling around her voice like soft rain. When the final chord faded into the soundproofed silence, she kept her eyes closed, waiting for the inevitable critique. Julian would have told her it was too sentimental. Marcus Bell was silent for a long moment, letting the echo of the song die completely. Then his voice, calm and thoughtful, crackled in her headphones. “That was beautiful, Eleanor,” he said, and the simple praise was so unexpected it almost made her flinch. “But it’s not right. Not yet.”

He beckoned her out of the glass booth and into the control room. He gestured for her to sit, then rewound the recording, playing back the last few lines. Her voice, pure and clear, filled the room. “It's life's illusions I recall / I really don't know life at all.” He stopped the tape. “You’re singing that like a young woman, full of regret and disillusionment,” he said, his gaze direct and kind. “But that’s not what the song is about at this point in the journey. Joni wrote it when she was young, but it’s a song for the old. It’s not about disillusionment. It’s about acceptance. It’s about wisdom.” He leaned forward, his tired eyes full of a fierce, artistic passion. “You, Eleanor Vance, have looked at life from both sides now. You have seen the quiet, chalk-dusted classroom and you have seen the roaring arena. You’ve seen the view from a small flat in Dover and a penthouse in Beverly Hills. You’ve earned the right to sing these words not as a lament, but as a statement of fact. When you sing ‘I really don’t know life at all,’ it shouldn’t be sad. It should be a moment of profound, liberating peace. The peace that comes from finally admitting you don’t have all the answers. That’s what these people we’re honouring learned. That’s the wisdom they found. Sing *that*.”

His words struck her with the force of a physical blow. He had seen straight through to the heart of her, to the core of her strange, divided life, and connected it to the soul of the song. It was the most astute piece of literary criticism she had ever heard. She walked back into the vocal booth, her mind racing, her understanding of the song completely reconfigured. This time, when she sang, she was not performing. She was testifying. When she sang of clouds, she saw the grey, low-slung ceiling over the English Channel. When she sang of love, she thought of her mother’s humming and Lily’s shy gratitude. When she sang of life, she thought of the view from her classroom window and the view from the window of this very hotel. Her voice was no longer just beautiful; it was imbued with the weight of her experience, with the quiet wisdom of a woman who had learned to be content with not knowing. When she reached the final line, she delivered it not as a whisper of defeat, but as a sigh of serene acceptance. The music ended, and in the silence, she heard Marcus whisper a single word into the intercom. “There.”

The day of the Grammy Awards was a sensory assault. Backstage was a glittering, high-speed ecosystem of impossibly beautiful people, frantic publicists, and an army of production staff all moving with the focused intensity of a military operation. Eleanor found a quiet, forgotten corner in a dimly lit corridor, a small oasis of calm away from the whirlwind. She leaned against a cold concrete wall, her evening dress—a simple, elegant column of deep blue silk Julian had insisted she wear—feeling like a costume from a play she had not yet rehearsed. She slid her hand into the small, hidden pocket she had sewn into the lining herself and closed her fingers around the smooth, familiar shape of the Dover stone. She held it tight, its solid, earthy reality a stark contrast to the glittering artifice all around her. Her phone buzzed. It was a text from Liam. ‘It’s the biggest room in the world, filled with the loneliest people. They’re all terrified. Sing for the ghosts, Eleanor, not for them. Break a leg.’ The message, so full of worldly cynicism and genuine warmth, made her smile. He understood. He saw the window.

The summons came all too soon. As she was escorted towards the stage, she passed dressing rooms with stars on the doors, catching glimpses of global superstars in various states of pre-performance anxiety, their entourages fluttering around them like nervous birds. It was just as Liam had said. The walk to the wings was a long, lonely journey down a darkened tunnel, the roar of the crowd growing louder with every step. She reached her position, hidden in the shadows, just as the arena lights dimmed. The giant screens on either side of the stage lit up, and the 'In Memoriam' segment began. The arena, which had been buzzing with chatter and excitement, fell into a profound, respectful silence. A lone piano began to play a gentle, mournful melody as the faces appeared on the screen, one by one. A legendary soul singer. A maverick rock guitarist. A beloved folk icon. A young rapper taken too soon. With each image, a wave of love and loss washed through the vast room. Eleanor watched them, letting their faces, their stories, their music fill her mind. Her own nervousness evaporated, replaced by a deep sense of purpose. This was not about her. She was merely a vessel, a voice chosen to articulate a collective grief. The final face faded from the screen. A single, pure white spotlight hit the center of the stage. That was her cue.

She walked into the light, her steps steady and sure, towards the lone microphone at the heart of the vast, silent darkness. The audience was a sea of famous faces, a living gallery of the music industry, but she did not look at them. She looked into the middle distance, to a place only she could see, and waited for the first notes from the piano. She began to sing, and her voice, clear and unadorned, filled the cavernous space. It was not the voice of a pop star or a diva; it was the voice of a woman telling a quiet truth. She sang of clouds that were ‘ice cream castles in the air’ and then became things that ‘only block the sun,’ and in her phrasing, you could hear the echo of both naïve dreams and hard-won experience. She sang of love as a fairy tale and then as something that leaves you dizzy and confused, and the thousands of people in the arena, people who had lived lives of extreme highs and devastating lows, felt the universal truth of the words pierce their professional cynicism. The camera panned across the faces in the front row: a pop queen with a single tear tracing a path through her perfect makeup, a hardened rock star staring at the stage with a look of raw, unguarded emotion, a legendary producer who simply closed his eyes, listening.

Then she came to the final verse, the summation of it all. As she sang, ‘I’ve looked at life from both sides now / From win and lose and still somehow,’ her voice swelled, not with power, but with a deep, resonant conviction. She thought of her classroom and this stage, of her students and these superstars, of Brenda and Liam, of the chalk dust and the starlight. It was all life. All of it. And as she delivered the final, devastating line, ‘I really don’t know life at all,’ her voice was not one of sorrow, but of gentle, liberating peace. It was a shared exhalation, a moment of profound, communal humility offered in the temple of fame. The last note of the piano hung in the air for an eternity, then faded into a silence so deep, so absolute, it felt more powerful than any sound. No one coughed. No one moved. The entire arena seemed to be holding its collective breath. Eleanor stood alone in the spotlight, her head slightly bowed, her work done. Then, slowly, as if coming out of a trance, one person began to clap. It was an old, legendary bluesman in the third row. Then another joined, and another, until a wave of warm, heartfelt, and deeply respectful applause washed over her, a sound not of wild adulation, but of profound gratitude.

Walking offstage, the adrenaline drained from her so quickly her knees felt weak. Marcus Bell was waiting for her in the wings. He didn’t speak. He simply met her eyes and gave her a single, sharp nod, a look of such profound professional approval it was worth more to her than any golden statuette. A moment later, a figure emerged from the shadows. It was the legendary bluesman from the third row, his face a roadmap of hard-lived years. He took her hand, his own dry and calloused, and held it for a moment. “Thank you, sister,” he said, his voice a gravelly whisper. “You sang the truth. God bless you.” And then he was gone. Backstage, the frantic energy was already ramping up for the next award presentation. Publicists rushed towards her, their phones already alight with offers and invitations to the most exclusive after-parties in the city. Eleanor shook her head politely, a small, serene smile on her face. “Thank you,” she said to the nearest one, her voice barely audible above the din, “but I have a very early flight to catch. And a lot of marking to return.”

Back in the silent, cavernous hotel room, the city of angels glittered below her like a fallen constellation. The glamour and noise of the awards show felt a million miles away, a dream she was already waking from. On the sleek designer desk, next to the small grey stone from Dover, sat the neat stack of sixty-two marked mock exams. Her return ticket lay beside them. She picked it up, her flight to London scheduled to depart in less than six hours. She had crossed the ocean, sung her truth at the heart of the empire of noise, and now she was going home. She had looked at life from both sides now, and she had discovered, to her profound and lasting peace, that she was equally at home in both. Her window looked out onto everything, and she was no longer afraid of the view.The journey home was an exercise in quiet decompression. The first-class cabin on the flight back to London was filled with a smattering of industry figures, their faces puffy from a weekend of after-parties, their conversations a low murmur of deals and gossip. Eleanor sat by the window, a novel resting unread in her lap, watching the vast, arid landscape of America shrink below her. She had declined the champagne this time, too, accepting a cup of tea that was disappointingly weak. Unlike the flight out, her canvas bag remained stowed away, its work complete. She felt a profound sense of lightness, the contented exhaustion of a job well and truly done. She had faced the twin beasts of global fame and her own deep-seated fear, and had found neither as monstrous as she had imagined. She had simply done her work, sung her song, and now she was going home. As the plane arced over the Atlantic, chasing the dawn, she finally slept, a deep, dreamless sleep, untroubled by either chalk dust or starlight. She woke to the familiar, comforting sight of a thick, grey blanket of cloud, and the gentle announcement from the captain that they were beginning their descent into London Heathrow. The sight of the rain-slicked runway and the soft, green patchwork of the English countryside felt like a physical welcome, a balm to her over-stimulated senses.

Tuesday morning was cold and bright, the winter sun glinting off the choppy waters of the Channel. She walked into Room 112 at her usual time, the scent of floor polish and old books a familiar greeting. The classroom was empty and silent, waiting. She unpacked her bag, placing Bartholomew’s bowl on the corner of the desk, his presence a quiet assertion that all was right with the world. Then, she took out the stack of sixty-two marked mock exams. She held them in her hands for a moment, the weight of them a tangible connection to the life she had chosen, the life she had fought to keep. The first bell rang, and a few moments later, her Year 11 class filed in. The change in them was palpable. They entered not with their usual clatter and chatter, but with a hushed, almost reverent quiet. They looked at her as if seeing her for the first time, this ordinary woman who stood in their ordinary classroom but who, just two days ago, had been a serene, glittering figure on a global stage. They had seen her hold a vast arena in a moment of profound silence, and now she was here, to talk to them about Macbeth. The cognitive dissonance was immense, and it had bred a deep, quiet respect.

"Good morning, everyone," she said, her voice calm and even, the same voice she always used. "I have your mock exam papers to return." A quiet intake of breath went through the room. She began to walk through the aisles, placing each paper face down on the desks, the rustle of the pages the only sound in the room. This simple, mundane act was charged with an unspoken significance. It was a promise kept. It was a statement that their work, their futures, mattered to her as much as any Grammy award. She saw it in their faces as they looked up at her; a flicker of understanding, of gratitude. She placed the last paper on Sam’s desk. He looked from his essay, covered in her neat red annotations, up to her face, his expression one of quiet, profound comprehension. He didn’t need to say anything. He understood that his analysis of guilt had travelled with her to Los Angeles and back, that it had been given as much careful thought in a first-class cabin over the Atlantic as it would have been in her quiet flat in Dover. He gave a small, almost imperceptible nod of acknowledgement, a gesture that meant more to her than any standing ovation. “Now,” she said, turning to face the board and picking up a piece of chalk, “let’s talk about the recurring motif of blood. Page forty-seven, please.” And just like that, they were back to work.

At break time, the staffroom offered a masterclass in affectionate nonchalance. Phil from PE slapped a copy of a newspaper down on the table in front of her. It showed a full-page picture of her on the Grammy stage, under a headline that read ‘The Stillness and the Storm’. “Not a bad photo, Vance,” he grinned. “Though I think your posture could use a bit of work. Core strength. We can work on that.” Brenda appeared with two mugs of tea, placing one on Eleanor’s desk without comment. “Jet lag,” she announced to the room at large, “is a myth invented by the middle classes to justify their expensive holidays. You’ve had a long weekend. That’s all.” She then proceeded to give Eleanor a detailed and withering critique of the tie worn by one of the award show hosts, before moving on to the school’s new, deeply flawed, recycling policy. It was perfect. It was normal. It was home. Sarah’s inevitable phone call was a blast of triumphant static from another universe. The album had gone to number one in twelve countries. The performance had been streamed over fifty million times in twenty-four hours. A world tour was being mooted. Promoters were offering fortunes. Eleanor listened patiently, a small smile on her face as she watched a group of her Year 7s attempting to play football in the windy playground below. “That’s wonderful, Sarah,” she said, when the producer finally paused for breath. “But you’ll have to schedule the planning meeting for the tour during the Easter holidays. I’ve got parents’ evening for Year 8 next Thursday, and it’s my turn to supervise the school trip to the Canterbury Tales exhibit the week after.” She heard Sarah sigh, a long, weary, but ultimately accepting sound. She had finally learned that the anchor was non-negotiable.

That evening, Eleanor sat in her armchair, a cup of tea warming her hands. Through the window, the lights of a ferry slid slowly across the dark water, a steadfast, predictable journey. Bartholomew swam in his bowl, a flash of iridescent colour in the lamplight. The world outside was abuzz with her name, her voice, her story. Her album was at the top of the charts. Her performance was being called legendary. She was, by any objective measure, a global star. But in the quiet of her living room, she was simply Eleanor Vance. She was not two halves of a whole, precariously balanced. She was one person. The woman who marked essays was the woman who sang. The woman who lived in this small, quiet flat was the woman who had stood on the world’s biggest stage. There was no longer a chasm between the two; there was only the window, and the window looked out onto everything.

The final bell on Thursday afternoon did not signal a release into a weekend of fame and travel. It was the summons for the Songwriting Club. She walked into Room 112 to find a small, dedicated group of students already waiting. They were huddled around a desk, listening intently as Finn, the shy Year 10 boy, quietly strummed a guitar and sang a new song. His voice was stronger now, his chords more confident. It was a song about the strange courage of the white cliffs, standing against the endless wind and sea. It was a song, she realised, about resilience. He finished, and looked up at her, his face flushed with the nervous pride of creation. The other students, Lily among them, offered quiet, constructive words of encouragement. Another girl, who had never sung before, tentatively offered a few lines of a poem she had written. Eleanor did not stand at the front of the room as a teacher, nor as a star. She sat with them, one of a circle of creators, listening, encouraging, enabling. This, she knew with a certainty that settled deep in her soul, was her true legacy. It was not the gold discs that would one day hang on her wall, nor the awards that might gather dust on her mantelpiece. It was this. This small, quiet room, filled with the sound of new voices, finding the courage to sing their own songs, to build their own windows, and to not be afraid of the view.

The chalk dust, a fine, pervasive sediment, coated everything in Room 112. It settled on the dog-eared spines of Shakespeare anthologies, filmed the dark screen of the unused television, and formed a ghostly film over Eleanor Vance’s worn, sensible shoes. She looked at her hands, the pale powder clinging to the creases around her knuckles, and felt a familiar, weary sense of permanence. This was her life, measured out in chalk dust and the shrill, metallic scream of the end-of-lesson bell. The bell shrieked then, right on cue, a sound that had bookended her days for twelve years, a Pavlovian jolt that meant either the welcome release into a sea of adolescent chatter or the grim summons back to the front line of Year 9 grammar.

Today, it meant release. A wave of relief, so profound it was almost dizzying, washed over her. The final bell. Not just for the day, or the week. The final bell before… everything.

As the classroom emptied in a chaotic surge of backpacks and burgeoning teenage social lives, Eleanor leaned against her desk, the cheap laminate cool against her back. Through the large window, she could see the grey, choppy waters of the Channel, a tireless procession of ferries ploughing their way to and from Calais, like weary beasts of burden. Dover. The white cliffs, a symbol of defiance and homecoming to the rest of the country, were, to her, simply the wallpaper of a life lived in quiet containment. A life of marking essays on the thematic significance of dreams in ‘Of Mice and Men’ while her own dreams gathered dust like the television in the corner.

Until now.

Her phone buzzed on the desk, rattling against a stray paperclip. The screen lit up with a name that still sent a flutter of utter disbelief through her chest: ‘Sarah - BGT’.

“Hello, Sarah,” she answered, her voice a little breathless. She tried to sound calm, professional, like a person who belonged in conversations with television producers.

“Elara, darling!” Sarah’s voice was a torrent of expensive coffee and London urgency. The producers had insisted on ‘Elara’. They said ‘Eleanor’ was too school-ma’amish. ‘Elara’, they’d cooed, was a star’s name. It sounded like a constellation. Eleanor Vance, English teacher, felt it sounded like a brand of yoghurt, but she hadn’t argued. “Just checking in. All set for tomorrow? Car’s picking you up at seven a.m. sharp. Hotel is sorted, right on the South Bank. You can see the studio from your window!”

“All set,” Eleanor confirmed, her eyes drifting back to the ferries. “Packing the last of my things now.”

“And you have… him?” Sarah asked, a note of careful hesitation in her voice.

Eleanor’s gaze shifted to the corner of her desk, to the small, perfectly spherical glass bowl. Inside, a flash of iridescent blue and furious red darted amongst the smooth, grey pebbles. “Bartholomew is ready for his close-up,” she said, a genuine smile finally breaking through her teacherly facade.

“Fantastic. Just… be careful with him, Elara. The crew are terrified. Health and Safety have had a field day. We’ve had to sign more waivers for the fish than for the man who sets himself on fire.”

“He’s not just a fish,” Eleanor said, her tone softer, more serious.

There was a brief pause on the line. “I know, darling. I know he’s your… mascot. Just get him to London in one piece. The nation is counting on you. No pressure!” Sarah laughed, a sharp, bright sound, and then the line went dead.

Eleanor picked up the bowl. Bartholomew, the guppy, swam in agitated little circles. He was, objectively, a magnificent specimen. A flame-tailed guppy of exquisite breeding, a living jewel. He had been a gift from Lily, a painfully shy Year 8 student who hadn't spoken a single word in class for a whole term. One day, after Eleanor had spent her lunch break helping her untangle the complexities of a poem, Lily had appeared at her classroom door with the bowl held in both hands. ‘He gets angry when he’s scared,’ she had whispered, the first words Eleanor had ever heard her speak. ‘But he likes it when you sing.’

And he did. When Eleanor practiced in her small flat, the television off, the essays unmarked, Bartholomew would stop his frantic darting and hang almost motionless in the water, his fins a gentle, hypnotic pulse. He had become her audience of one, her tiny, silent critic. Taking him to the first audition had been an impulse, a desperate need for a piece of her real, quiet life in that terrifying, artificial world. She’d hidden the little bowl in her tote bag, feeling ridiculous. But as she’d waited in the wings, heart hammering against her ribs, she’d hummed the opening bars of her song, and peering into the bag, she’d seen him, calm and still.

She had walked on stage, placed the small bowl on a stool beside the microphone stand, and explained, her voice trembling, that he was her accompanist. The judges had exchanged amused, pitying glances. Simon Cowell had looked bored. And then she had sung. She’d sung an old, heartbreaking Celtic lament, her voice soaring into the vast, silent darkness of the theatre, a voice that no one in her life, not her colleagues, not her distant family, knew she possessed. It was a voice she had locked away after her mother died, a voice she had only rediscovered in the solitude of her flat, with only a guppy for company.

And in the middle of the song, she had glanced over, and Bartholomew, caught in the beam of a single spotlight, had been perfectly, beautifully still. It had become her thing. The Lady with the Fish. The press loved it. It was quirky, eccentric, quintessentially British. Amanda had given her the Golden Buzzer, raining gold confetti down on her and the bewildered guppy, and her life had split into two distinct realities: the chalk-dusted life of Eleanor, and the glittering, terrifying, incandescent life of Elara.

“Right then, Barty,” she murmured, covering the top of the bowl with cling film and punching a few small air holes. “Time to go and win this thing.”

The staffroom was a fug of instant coffee and low-level complaint. Brenda, the Head of Maths, who had been at the school since the dawn of time, eyed the fishbowl as Eleanor placed it carefully on the table.

“Still carting that thing around with you?” Brenda grunted, stirring her coffee with vicious circular movements. “Thought you’d have won a goldfish by now. Or at least a decent-sized carp.”

“He’s my lucky charm, Brenda,” Eleanor said, forcing a brightness she didn’t feel. The anxiety was a cold knot in her stomach. The final. The actual, televised-to-fifteen-million-people final of Britain’s Got Talent. It felt like a bizarre dream she was about to wake from.

“Lottery tickets, that’s what it is,” Brenda continued, taking a loud sip. “Setting people up for a fall. I saw that poor lad last year, the tap-dancing juggler. Crying his eyes out. Working in a call centre now, my sister’s neighbour’s boy knows him. A call centre. From the Royal Variety Performance to ‘have you tried turning it off and on again?’ That’s what you’ve got to look forward to, Eleanor.”

“It’s a bit of fun,” she said weakly.

“Fun?” Brenda scoffed. “You’ve got your face plastered on the side of a bus, love. We’re past ‘fun’. This is national spectacle. Just don’t forget to mention Dover Grammar School for Girls when you’re weeping on Ant and Dec’s shoulders.”

She was right, of course. It had long since spiralled past ‘fun’. The local paper had run a front-page story. ‘DOVER’S DIVA’. Her students followed her on social media accounts she’d been forced to create. They treated her with a strange new mixture of awe and familiarity, asking for selfies in the corridor. It was exhilarating and deeply unsettling. She was still the same Eleanor Vance who got nervous speaking in staff meetings, yet now, millions of people had an opinion on her dress sense, her song choices, her relationship with a small tropical fish.

She packed the last of her marking into a canvas bag, her movements automatic. Essays on ‘An Inspector Calls’. She’d mark them in the hotel. It would keep her grounded. It would be something to do with her hands other than wring them. She looked around the staffroom, at the peeling notices on the corkboard, the precarious towers of unmarked books, the biscuit tin with only a few sad crumbs of a broken digestive remaining. It was shabby, and frustrating, and so deeply, achingly familiar. It was real. And tomorrow, she would stand on a stage of pure, dazzling artifice and sing for her life. The chasm between those two worlds felt terrifyingly wide, and she was terrified of falling.

Walking to her car, she cradled the fishbowl in one arm like a newborn. The school building stood behind her, a squat, functional brick monolith against a sky the colour of dishwater. She had hated it sometimes, felt trapped by its routine and its relentless demands. But tonight, it looked like a sanctuary. A place where the stakes were as low as a missing piece of homework.

She placed Bartholomew’s bowl in a specially-designed box on the passenger seat, padded with tea towels and a hot water bottle to maintain the temperature. The preparations for transporting the fish had become a military operation. She drove away from the school, past the terraced houses with their satellite dishes turned like hopeful faces to the sky, and towards the motorway. London. The final.

Her heart hammered a frantic, syncopated rhythm against her ribs. She was Elara. She was the Lady with the Fish. She was a constellation. She was a brand of yoghurt. She was a teacher from Dover who was in way, way over her head. She glanced at the bowl. Bartholomew, seemingly agitated by the motion of the car, darted from one side to the other. His fins, usually so graceful, were a frantic blur. ‘He gets angry when he’s scared,’ Lily’s whisper echoed in her head.

“It’s alright, Barty,” she whispered, her own voice tight with fear. “It’s alright. We just have to be brave for one more night.”

The motorway was a river of red and white light, pulling her inexorably towards the capital. The familiar green of the Kent countryside blurred into an impressionistic smear outside her window, the rolling hills flattening as the city’s gravitational pull intensified. Each signpost—Maidstone, Dartford Crossing, M25—felt like a station of the cross on a pilgrimage she hadn’t chosen, but was now compelled to complete. Brenda’s words echoed in the hum of the tyres on tarmac. *A call centre.* Was that the inevitable anticlimax? Was this brief, blinding flash of fame just a prelude to an even deeper obscurity, one made worse by the memory of what it felt like to be seen? She tightened her grip on the steering wheel, a muscle in her jaw twitching. She wasn't a tap-dancing juggler. She was a woman who had found her voice, and she would not let it be silenced again, not by fear, and certainly not by Brenda’s weary cynicism.

London did not arrive so much as metastasize, the urban sprawl creeping into the landscape until it had consumed everything. The sky, which had been a moody grey over the Channel, now seemed tinged with a sickly orange glow. Rows of identical houses gave way to tower blocks, their lit windows like a million unblinking eyes all watching her. It was a scale of humanity that felt crushing. In Dover, she knew the rhythm of the town, the faces in the supermarket, the shortcut through the park. Here, she was utterly anonymous, just another car in a torrent of traffic, and yet, paradoxically, she was on her way to an event where fifteen million people would know her name. Or, at least, the name they had given her. The contradiction was dizzying, a kind of vertigo that made her feel unmoored from reality itself.

The hotel on the South Bank was a gleaming monument to modern luxury. A doorman in a top hat, looking like a character from one of the Dickens novels she taught, opened her car door with a placid smile, not batting an eyelid as she carefully retrieved the box containing Bartholomew. The lobby was a cavern of polished marble and hushed tones, smelling faintly of lilies and money. When she reached the check-in desk, the receptionist’s professional smile widened into one of genuine recognition. “Miss Vance! Elara! It is so wonderful to have you with us. We’ve been watching your journey. We’re all rooting for you.” Eleanor mumbled a thank you, feeling the heat rise in her cheeks. She was a public commodity now, a story to be consumed, a journey to be watched. She clutched the box a little tighter, a fragile anchor in a sea of overwhelming strangeness.

Her room was on the twentieth floor, a sleek, minimalist space of chrome and grey fabrics. It was less a room and more a viewing platform for the city. A single, vast window made up the entire far wall, and framed within it, like a terrifying piece of performance art, was the London skyline. And there, just across the dark, swirling water of the Thames, was the studio. It was squat and unassuming from this distance, yet it pulsed with a latent energy, a silent promise of the noise and light and judgment that awaited her. She could see the broadcast tower, a red light blinking in the twilight. She imagined the signal flowing out from it tomorrow night, carrying her voice into living rooms in Cornwall and Cumbria, into pubs in Glasgow and terraced houses in Belfast. The thought was so vast, so utterly incomprehensible, that she had to sit down on the edge of the king-sized bed, her legs suddenly unsteady.

Before she did anything else, she attended to Bartholomew. She carefully unwrapped him, removed the cling film, and placed his bowl on the sleek, glass-topped desk, right in front of the spectacular, intimidating view. The tiny, iridescent fish against the sprawling metropolis. It was her entire life in a single tableau: the small, private, precious thing she had to protect, set against the enormous, impersonal world she was expected to conquer. Bartholomew swam a few lazy laps, his fins catching the lamplight, seemingly unbothered by his new, vertiginous surroundings. He was the only thing in this entire, bewildering new chapter that felt truly hers. He was the link back to Lily’s whisper, to the quiet solitude of her flat, to the woman she was before the golden buzzer changed everything.

She unpacked her small suitcase, the few dresses the BGT wardrobe department had approved of looking alien and theatrical next to her sensible cardigans. At the bottom of the bag was the canvas tote containing the stack of Year 10 essays. She pulled them out, the familiar weight of them a comfort in her hands. She spread them on the desk beside Bartholomew’s bowl. *An Inspector Calls*. The bold, looping handwriting of a student named Chloe, the cramped, spidery script of a boy named Sam. She picked one up, uncapped a red pen, and read the opening sentence. The simple, familiar act of marking was a ritual, a tether to the Eleanor who knew exactly who she was. Outside, London glittered, a galaxy of hostile stars. In here, for a few moments, she was just an English teacher with work to do. And that, more than anything else, helped her breathe.

Hours passed, measured not in the shriek of a bell but in the scratch of her red pen against cheap paper. ‘The Inspector is a catalyst for the family’s guilt,’ wrote Sam, his handwriting leaning forward as if in a hurry to get to the end of the sentence. ‘He doesn’t have a real identity, so he can be whatever they need him to be. He is a mirror.’ Eleanor paused, the pen hovering over the page. A mirror. She felt a phantom chill, a sense of being watched not just by the city outside but by the millions of people who had formed an opinion of her. They saw what they wanted to see: a quirky spinster, a hidden talent, a sob story, an eccentric with a fish. Elara, the Lady with the Fish. It was a character, a two-dimensional reflection in the vast, unforgiving mirror of public opinion. She circled the sentence and wrote ‘An excellent and insightful point, Sam. Develop this.’ in the margin, her own handwriting a neat, controlled cursive that felt like a relic from another age.

The pile of marked essays grew, a small redoubt of normalcy on the polished desk. Each tick, each comment, was a small act of defiance against the glittering panic outside her window. This was real work. It had tangible results, shaping the thoughts of a fourteen-year-old boy in Dover. What she was doing tomorrow felt like the opposite; it was ephemeral, a spectacle of light and sound that would be analysed, voted upon, and then forgotten by next week, replaced by a new circus. She finished the final essay, placed it neatly on the stack, and capped her pen. The silence that rushed in to fill the void was immense, broken only by the distant, mournful siren of a boat on the Thames. The work was done. There was nothing left to anchor her.

A sudden, sharp rap on the door made her jump, her heart leaping into her throat. It was too late for room service, too early for the morning call. She hesitated, her hand hovering over the door’s security latch. It came again, louder this time, followed by a muffled burst of laughter. Cautiously, she opened the door a crack. Standing in the hallway were the three members of ‘Kinetic’, a boyband barely out of their teens, whose synchronised backflips and perfectly auto-tuned harmonies had made them the bookies’ favourite. They were a riot of styled hair, artfully ripped jeans, and blindingly white trainers.

“Elara!” said the lead singer, the one with the floppy fringe and a diamond stud in his ear. His name was Josh, or maybe Leo. She could never keep them straight. “We were just heading down to the bar. The producers have put a tab on for the finalists! You coming?” He craned his neck to see into her room. “Is that him? The fish? Wicked.” His bandmates crowded behind him, peering in with the same intense, fleeting curiosity they might give a viral video. “We’re doing a live stream from the bar, our manager thinks it’s great for engagement. You should come on, say hi to the fans. The #FishLady hashtag is trending like crazy.”

Eleanor felt a hundred years old. The gulf between her world of chalk dust and Celtic laments and their world of hashtags and engagement was too wide to be bridged by a hotel corridor. “That’s very kind of you,” she said, her voice sounding formal and stiff even to her own ears. “But I think I need an early night. Big day tomorrow.” The boys exchanged glances, a flicker of pity in their eyes. The old dear, the schoolteacher, tucked up in bed while the real stars were building their brand. “Suit yourself,” Josh/Leo shrugged, the professional smile already back in place. “Don’t be a stranger! Break a leg, yeah?” And with another burst of loud chatter and cologne, they were gone, their youthful energy echoing down the hallway as they headed towards the lifts, their phones already out and glowing.

She closed the door and leaned against it, the cool wood a comfort against her back. She felt as though she had just been visited by emissaries from another planet, a planet where life was lived through a screen and measured in likes. Brenda’s cynical voice returned, a nagging ghost in the luxurious room. *National spectacle.* She looked from the stack of essays to Bartholomew, who was now flitting nervously around his bowl, his beautiful tail a blur of distress. The encounter, as brief as it was, had unsettled him. It had unsettled her. She was a novelty act. The Fish Lady. A quirky talking point to fill the time between the real contenders, the shiny, marketable young men who knew how to work the camera and engage with the fans.

A wave of anger, sharp and clarifying, cut through the anxiety. She would not be a novelty. She would not be a quirky footnote in someone else’s story of success. She had not rediscovered her voice only to have it packaged and sold as a gimmick. She walked to the window, forcing herself to look at the studio, at the city, at the whole overwhelming machine. They had taken her name, but they could not take her song. Her final song choice had been a battle. The producers had wanted something upbeat, a pop ballad, something from a West End show that would showcase her ‘surprising power’. She had refused. She had insisted, with a stubbornness that had surprised them and herself, on a song that meant something.

It was an old Irish folk song, one her mother used to sing to her as a child, her voice a low, clear melody in the quiet of her childhood bedroom. *She Moved Through the Fair.* It was the last song she had ever heard her mother sing, a few weeks before the illness stole her breath and then her life. For years, Eleanor hadn't been able to even think of the melody without a knot of grief tightening in her chest. It was the song that had sealed her voice away. And it would be the song that set it free. Singing it tomorrow would not be for the fifteen million viewers, or for the judges, or for the recording contract that might follow. It would be for her mother. It would be for the painfully shy girl in her flat who had hummed to a guppy because she was too afraid to let anyone else hear.

She looked at Bartholomew, her tiny, captive audience. “Alright, Barty,” she whispered, her voice soft but steady. “One last rehearsal.” She began to hum, the ancient, haunting melody filling the sterile silence of the hotel room. It was a song of love and ghosts, of a promise that transcended even death. As the notes formed in her throat, she saw him, through the glass of his small world. Bartholomew stopped his frantic darting. His fins, a moment ago a blur of panic, relaxed. He hung motionless in the water, a jewel of blue and red, perfectly, beautifully still, listening. He was her audience of one, her first and most important critic. He was her mirror. And in his stillness, she saw not the frightened teacher or the novelty act, but a woman who was ready to sing.

The morning arrived not with the gentle grey light of the Dover coast, but as a sharp, clinical slash of white across the hotel room’s expensive carpet. Eleanor had not so much slept as drifted in a shallow, anxious tide of consciousness, the city’s endless hum a constant murmur beneath the surface of her thoughts. The first thing she saw when she opened her eyes was the skyline, stark and immense, the studio across the river no longer a distant promise but an immediate, concrete fact. Her stomach clenched. This was it. The day of the national spectacle. A young woman with a clipboard and an aggressively cheerful demeanour knocked on her door at precisely seven-thirty, handing her a laminated schedule that mapped out every minute of her day until the live show began. Wardrobe at 09:00, soundcheck at 10:30, pre-recorded interview at 12:00, lunch at 13:00 (a pre-packed salad, she noted with a grimace), make-up from 14:00. Her life was a call sheet.

The journey to the studio was in a blacked-out car that smelled of leather and air freshener. She held Bartholomew’s carrier box on her lap, the gentle sloshing of the water a tiny, rhythmic counterpoint to the frantic thrumming in her own veins. As they pulled up to a security gate, she caught a glimpse of the crowds already gathering, faces pressed against barriers, phone cameras held aloft. A banner, hand-painted on a bedsheet, was visible for a fleeting second. It read ‘WE LOVE YOU ELARA & THE FISH’. The name, her new name, felt like a costume she hadn’t yet put on. The car descended into an underground parking garage, a concrete underworld buzzing with activity, and the brief connection to the outside world was severed. She was inside the machine now.

Backstage was a disorienting maze of corridors, cables taped to the floor like cryptic sigils, and rooms identified by stark, printed signs. ‘Kinetic’. ‘Audio 2’. ‘Catering’. The air was thick with the scent of hairspray and nervous sweat. People with headsets and lanyards hurried past, their faces tight with purpose, their conversations a clipped, urgent jargon she couldn’t begin to decipher. It was the frantic, high-stakes inverse of the familiar, lethargic shuffle of the staffroom at Dover Grammar. She was guided to a small, brightly lit dressing room, her name – ‘ELARA’ – taped to the door. Inside was a mirror framed with bare, brutally honest lightbulbs, a rack of shimmering dresses that the wardrobe department had selected for her, and a single chair. It was anonymous, functional, and terrifyingly lonely. Her first act was to carefully unbox Bartholomew and place his bowl on the corner of the dressing table, a tiny, silent assertion of her own identity in this sterile space.

Sarah, the producer, swept in an hour later, a whirlwind of black coffee and crisis management. “Darling! You look… rested,” she lied, her eyes scanning Eleanor’s face for any signs of a complete breakdown. “Wardrobe are thrilled with the blue dress, it’ll catch the light beautifully. Now, listen. When you do the interview with Dec later, he’s going to ask you about your mother.” Eleanor’s hand, which had been stroking the rim of Bartholomew’s bowl, froze. “We’ve talked about the narrative. The song is a tribute. It’s about finding your voice again after loss. Don’t be afraid to get emotional. The public connects with vulnerability. It’s authentic.” Eleanor stared at her. Authentic, choreographed emotion. A profound, private grief packaged for mass consumption. “It’s a beautiful story, Elara. Let people in,” Sarah finished, patting her on the shoulder before her headset crackled and she was called away to deal with a pyrotechnic that had failed its safety test.

Left alone again, Eleanor looked at her reflection. The woman staring back was a stranger. Her mousy brown hair had been given ‘subtle, TV-ready highlights’, and her face felt naked without the faint dusting of chalk that usually clung to it. She felt like a fraud. She was about to go on national television and monetise her own heartbreak for the sake of a 'beautiful story'. Brenda’s cynicism felt less like pessimism and more like prophecy. She pulled her phone from her bag, scrolling through a dozen meaningless notifications from the social media accounts the show had made her set up. And then she saw it. An email from the school’s main office, with the subject line ‘A Message for Ms. Vance’. She clicked it open. It was a scanned image of a piece of notepaper, folded in half. On it, in a shy, neat hand, were a few simple words. ‘Good luck Miss. We are all watching. Lily. P.S. He likes the high notes best.’

A sob, sharp and unexpected, caught in Eleanor’s throat. Lily. The quiet girl with the fish. The beginning of it all. It wasn’t a story, it wasn’t a narrative, it was a real connection, a whispered secret in a noisy school corridor that had somehow led her here. This message was not for Elara, the constellation, the brand of yoghurt. It was for Ms. Vance, her teacher. It was a tether, thrown across the chasm from her real life, and she clung to it. She looked from the note to the fish, then back to her own reflection in the mirror. The face was still unfamiliar, but for the first time that day, the eyes looked like her own. She knew what she was singing for. It wasn't for the narrative, or the votes, or the ghost of Brenda’s schadenfreude. It was for her mother’s memory, for a shy girl named Lily, and for the quiet woman who had finally found the courage to make a sound. The high notes. Yes. She would give them the high notes.

The transformation began under the soft, precise strokes of a make-up artist’s brush. Eleanor sat perfectly still in the chair, a passive canvas upon which the brand of ‘Elara’ was being painted. Powders settled into the lines of her face, a finer, more glamorous dust than the chalk she was used to, designed to catch the light, not the afternoon sun through a classroom window. The artist, a young man with kind eyes and a low, soothing voice, worked with quiet concentration, oblivious to the profound internal shift that had taken place in the woman before him. While he blended and shaded, Eleanor closed her eyes and retreated inwards. She was not here, in a brightly lit dressing room in London. She was in a small, pebble-dashed house in Dover, listening to her mother hum as she pegged washing on the line, the melody of *She Moved Through the Fair* snagging on the sea breeze. She was standing in a dusty corridor, accepting a small glass bowl from a student who had just found her voice. These were the things she held onto, the true things, even as a stranger glued false eyelashes to her eyelids.

The blue dress was next. It was made of a deep, midnight-blue silk that shimmered under the harsh lights, the colour of the Channel at dusk. When she had first seen it, it had felt like a costume for a person she didn't know, a glamorous imposter. But now, as she zipped it up, the cool fabric settling against her skin, it felt different. It felt like armour. It was a uniform for this strange, singular battlefield. She stood before the mirror, the woman in the glittering dress, the highlighted hair, the carefully constructed face, and she did not see a stranger. She saw Eleanor Vance, an English teacher from Dover, wearing what the situation demanded. She was not a constellation; she was a woman on a mission, and this was the required attire. The vulnerability Sarah had spoken of would not come from a feigned tear, but from the song itself, a truth so profound it needed no embellishment.

“Elara? Two minutes.” A young runner with a headset and a terrified expression poked her head around the door, her eyes wide. The sound from the corridor rushed in, a wall of noise – the distant, percussive beat of Kinetic’s final number, the roar of the crowd, the crackle of instructions from a dozen walkie-talkies. The air itself seemed to vibrate with anticipation. Eleanor nodded, her own heart giving a single, hard thump against her ribs. It was time. She turned to the dressing table and the small, still point in her chaotic new universe. With methodical care, she placed a clean, smooth stone over the top of Bartholomew’s bowl, a weight to stop the water from sloshing too violently. It was a stone from the beach at Dover, worn smooth by a thousand tides. A piece of home. “Right then, Barty,” she whispered, her voice barely audible above the din. “The high notes.”

Carrying the bowl in both hands, she followed the runner down the narrow corridor. The walk to the wings was a journey through the frantic, beating heart of the television machine. She passed one of the Kinetic boys, already flushed with victory, shouting into his phone to his manager. She saw a comedian, pale and sweating, muttering his opening line to himself over and over again. Everyone was caught in their own bubble of terror and ambition. The noise grew louder, a physical pressure against her eardrums, as they reached the cavernous space behind the stage. The heat from the lights was intense, washing over her in waves. Kinetic’s song ended in a final, explosive crash of synthesisers and a roar from the audience that felt like it could shake the foundations of the building.

In the sudden, relative quiet as the applause died down and the hosts’ voices filled the theatre, she found a small pocket of shadow away from the frantic stagehands. She was next. Ant and Dec were doing their patter, their familiar, cheerful voices echoing around her. She could hear them say her name. ‘Elara’. She took a deep breath, the air thick with the smell of dry ice. She looked down at the bowl. In the dim light, she could just make out the flicker of blue and red. He was darting again, agitated by the noise and the movement. She brought the bowl closer to her face, shielding it with her body, and began to hum, so softly that only she and the fish could possibly hear. It was the opening bar of her song, the haunting, ancient melody that held all her grief and all her hope. She watched, her focus narrowing until the entire world consisted of nothing but a small glass bowl. And she saw it. The frantic darting slowed. The furious red tail relaxed. Bartholomew floated, suspended, a living jewel in the darkness, listening. A stage manager appeared at her elbow. He didn’t speak, just gave a single, sharp nod. It was time to walk into the light.

Stepping from the chaotic darkness of the wings into the glare of the stage was like diving into a sun. The light was a physical presence, a wall of heat and white intensity that bleached the world of all colour and detail. It was followed by the sound, a colossal, unified roar from thousands of unseen people that pressed in on her from all sides. For a terrifying second, her senses were overwhelmed, her mind blank. But the weight of the bowl in her hands, the cool, solid glass and the gentle slosh of the water, was an undeniable reality. She focused on it, a tiny, portable anchor, and put one worn, sensible shoe in front of the other, walking a path only she could see towards the centre of the immense, empty stage.

There, waiting for her, was a single high stool and a microphone stand, an island of stillness in a sea of light and noise. With the slow, deliberate care of someone performing a sacred rite, she placed Bartholomew’s bowl on the stool. The small, grey stone from Dover beach sat on top, a humble, earthy counterpoint to the dazzling artifice surrounding it. She adjusted the microphone, her fingers brushing the cool metal, and took a half-step back. From here, the audience was an abstract concept, a vast darkness pricked with the countless, tiny lights of mobile phones. The judges’ table was a distant, glowing tableau; she could see the shape of Simon Cowell’s familiar stillness, the glint of Amanda Holden’s dress, but their faces were indistinct. This was her space now. She, the microphone, and the fish.

The hosts’ final words of introduction faded, and a silence descended upon the theatre that was more intimidating than the roar. It was a weighted silence, heavy with the expectation of fifteen million people. A single, sharp spotlight narrowed, isolating her and the bowl in a brilliant circle of white, plunging everything else into shadow. In that vast, expectant hush, she was utterly alone. She closed her eyes for a single heartbeat, not in prayer, but in remembrance. She thought of her mother’s hands in the garden. She thought of Lily’s whispered words. She drew a breath, not the shallow, panicked gasp of her first audition, but a deep, steadying lungful of air. And then, she sang.

The first note was not a belt, not a cry for attention. It was a thread of sound, impossibly pure and clear, that seemed to emerge not from her throat but from the silence itself. It was the opening line of *She Moved Through the Fair*, and her voice, unadorned by any instrumental backing, was as stark and beautiful as a winter landscape. It was a voice that held the echo of folk clubs and rainy Tuesday nights, a voice that knew of loss. The atmosphere in the theatre shifted palpably. A collective tension, a readiness to be entertained, dissolved into something else entirely – a deep, communal listening. The rustling stopped. The scattered coughs died away. On the judging panel, Simon, who had been leaning back in his chair with an air of professional detachment, slowly leaned forward, his elbows coming to rest on the desk, his expression one of sharp, undivided focus.

As the tragic story of the song unfolded, Eleanor allowed herself to glance at the bowl. There, in the focused beam of the spotlight, Bartholomew was a suspended miracle. His frantic energy was gone, replaced by a perfect, hypnotic stillness, his fins a gentle, almost imperceptible pulse of blue and red against the dark pebbles. He was a living jewel, captive and calm, her audience of one. The sight of him, so small and so serene in the heart of this colossal spectacle, filled her with a fierce, protective love. He was her truth. He was the secret she had kept, now shared with the world. He was the proof that this was real.
